HAIRDRESSING STICKS
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4342 A
Culture: MANGBETU?
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: WOOD
Dimensions: L:23 W:21 (LINED NEXT TO EACH OTHER L:23.4 W:22.9) (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: HAIRDRESSING STICK
Category: EQUIPMENT
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: EQURRA. Sticks used for arranging the braided string over the hair. Not all women use it. I took a photograph of NENSIMA with the sticks in use. After they arrive with the string above the forehead they push these sticks underneath the partly finished portion and then they continue the process with much less trouble. There is another string used behind; the braided string does not lay about the hair in circles, but when reaching the back the braided string is folded and carried forward. The string behind is drawn between the fold, there is a slight distance left behind between the braided string that allows at the withdrawal of the stick to tie up the braided string by simply pulling it downward. See photograph. Nearly every day the hair is newly arranged by simply laying with a needle one round near the other. Indeed in a well made hairdress not a single hair is sticking out between the different braided strings. The women are naturally very proud of their hairdress and it is only with great difficulties that permission is obtained to cut the hair off.
Exhibition History
• AFRICAN REFLECTIONS: ART FROM NORTHEASTERN ZAIRE. AMNH, NEW YORK, NY. June 1990 - February 1994
Exhibition Label: Wooden sticks, used for arranging the hair.
Manuscript Catalog Related Archives Finding Aids About Lang-Chapin Congo Expedition

APRON
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4345
Culture: MANGBETU?
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: PLANT FIBER, DYE, CORD, LEAVES
Dimensions: L:24 W:20 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: APRON
Category: COSTUME
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: NEGWE. The portion of their clothes that covers their hind. It is very simply adjusted. The lengthened piece on the back is simply pushed down the natural furrow, the string between the narrow and flat piece. The MANGBETU women do not like that their hind quarters are exposed to the looks of men, but when making their toilet they are well satisfied to take a piece not larger than the width of a finger for covering this portion of their backside. In front they take then a piece of bark cloth the size of their hand, so as to cover just that portion which is covered with hair. In this one branch the women create the most astonishing variety of patterns and each woman changes the pattern continually. Some even decorate it by cutting in black human figures, monkeys, etc. (See Nos. 1050 - 1051). As a rule they use only banana leaves in making them. The rough blackened leaves are the reddish leaves that cover the long flours [sic, flowers?] of plantains. They are easily blackened and have a greater resistance. They also use occasionally leaves of corn. They are very white ones, like No. 1022. Others have a sort of hood, like Nos. 1017, 1031, 1032, 1034, which very nicely covers the hollow near the base of the spine. Formerly much in use, now it is difficult to get them. There are only two women in the village of OKONDO who know how to make them. They are woven of bast. Some have a lengthened portion that lays flat on the back like No. l018 & 1049. They arrange first the leaves and s...ew bast through. They sometimes produce good patterns as may be seen also by Nos. 986, 988, 983 & 985. Very few of the women are able to do this kind of work. Usually it takes about a day to make one of these covers for their back, but they never work continuously. As may be seen by No. 1052, the leaves are first sliced deep and pressed between the mats of their bed. They sleep upon a week or so sometimes there are several bunches like this between the mats for future working. The outside leaves are then collected and blackened. They usually work one hour or two in the morning (before they go to other work) in making these covers and in this may spend several days. The women admire the creations of their friends and the more experienced ones very often give their welcome advice. No. 1055 shows the beginning of a cover. They only use a needle, (best to sew and tie) a pointed stick (to make the knot) a knife to cut the designs. The designs are cut out without making preliminary indications for the pattern (free hand).Show More >>
Manuscript Catalog Related Archives Finding Aids About Lang-Chapin Congo Expedition

Some even decorate it by cutting in black human figures, monkeys, etc. (See Nos. 1050 - 1051). As a rule they use only banana leaves in making them. The rough blackened leaves are the reddish leaves that cover the long flours [sic, flowers?] of plantains. They are easily blackened and have a greater resistance. They also use occasionally leaves of corn. They are very white ones, like No. 1022. Others have a sort of hood, like Nos. 1017, 1031, 1032, 1034, which very nicely covers the hollow near the base of the spine. Formerly much in use, now it is difficult to get them. There are only two women in the village of OKONDO who know how to make them. They are woven of bast. Some have a lengthened portion that lays flat on the back like No. l018 & 1049. They arrange first the leaves and s...ew bast through. They sometimes produce good patterns as may be seen also by Nos. 986, 988, 983 & 985. Very few of the women are able to do this kind of work. Usually it takes about a day to make one of these covers for their back, but they never work continuously. As may be seen by No. 1052, the leaves are first sliced deep and pressed between the mats of their bed. They sleep upon a week or so sometimes there are several bunches like this between the mats for future working. The outside leaves are then collected and blackened. They usually work one hour or two in the morning (before they go to other work) in making these covers and in this may spend several days. The women admire the creations of their friends and the more experienced ones very often give their welcome advice. No. 1055 shows the beginning of a cover. They only use a needle, (best to sew and tie) a pointed stick (to make the knot) a knife to cut the designs. The designs are cut out without making preliminary indications for the pattern (free hand).Show More >>
Manuscript Catalog Related Archives Finding Aids About Lang-Chapin Congo Expedition

Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: NEGWE. The portion of their clothes that covers their hind. It is very simply adjusted. The lengthened piece on the back is simply pushed down the natural furrow, the string between the narrow and flat piece. The MANGBETU women do not like that their hind quarters are exposed to the looks of men, but when making their toilet they are well satisfied to take a piece not larger than the width of a finger for covering this portion of their backside. In front they take then a piece of bark cloth the size of their hand, so as to cover just that portion which is covered with hair. In this one branch the women create the most astonishing variety of patterns and each woman changes the pattern continually. Some even decorate it by cutting in black human figures, monkeys, etc. (See Nos. 1050 - 1051). As a rule they use only banana leaves in making them. The rough blackened leaves are the reddish leaves that cover the long flours [sic, flowers?] of plantains. They are easily blackened and have a greater resistance. They also use occasionally leaves of corn. They are very white ones, like No. 1022. Others have a sort of hood, like Nos. 1017, 1031, 1032, 1034, which very nicely covers the hollow near the base of the spine. Formerly much in use, now it is difficult to get them. There are only two women in the village of OKONDO who know how to make them. They are woven of bast. Some have a lengthened portion that lays flat on the back like No. l018 & 1049. They arrange first the leaves and s...ew bast through. They sometimes produce good patterns as may be seen also by Nos. 986, 988, 983 & 985. Very few of the women are able to do this kind of work. Usually it takes about a day to make one of these covers for their back, but they never work continuously. As may be seen by No. 1052, the leaves are first sliced deep and pressed between the mats of their bed. They sleep upon a week or so sometimes there are several bunches like this between the mats for future working. The outside leaves are then collected and blackened. They usually work one hour or two in the morning (before they go to other work) in making these covers and in this may spend several days. The women admire the creations of their friends and the more experienced ones very often give their welcome advice. No. 1055 shows the beginning of a cover. They only use a needle, (best to sew and tie) a pointed stick (to make the knot) a knife to cut the designs. The designs are cut out without making preliminary indications for the pattern (free hand).Show More >>

Catalog No: 90.1/ 4365
Culture: MANGBETU?
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: PLANT FIBER, CORD, DYE, LEAVES
Dimensions: L:25.5 W:22.5 H:7 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: APRON
Category: COSTUME
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: NEGWE. The portion of their clothes that covers their hind. It is very simply adjusted. The lengthened piece on the back is simply pushed down the natural furrow, the string between the narrow and flat piece. The MANGBETU women do not like that their hind quarters are exposed to the looks of men, but when making their toilet they are well satisfied to take a piece not larger than the width of a finger for covering this portion of their backside. In front they take then a piece of bark cloth the size of their hand, so as to cover just that portion which is covered with hair. In this one branch the women create the most astonishing variety of patterns and each woman changes the pattern continually. Some even decorate it by cutting in black human figures, monkeys, etc. (See Nos. 1050 - 1051). As a rule they use only banana leaves in making them. The rough blackened leaves are the reddish leaves that cover the long flours [sic, flowers?] of plantains. They are easily blackened and have a greater resistance. They also use occasionally leaves of corn. They are very white ones, like No. 1022. Others have a sort of hood, like Nos. 1017, 1031, 1032, 1034, which very nicely covers the hollow near the base of the spine. Formerly much in use, now it is difficult to get them. There are only two women in the village of OKONDO who know how to make them. They are woven of bast. Some have a lengthened portion that lays flat on the back like No. l018 & 1049. They arrange first the leaves and s...ew bast through. They sometimes produce good patterns as may be seen also by Nos. 986, 988, 983 & 985. Very few of the women are able to do this kind of work. Usually it takes about a day to make one of these covers for their back, but they never work continuously. As may be seen by No. 1052, the leaves are first sliced deep and pressed between the mats of their bed. They sleep upon a week or so sometimes there are several bunches like this between the mats for future working. The outside leaves are then collected and blackened. They usually work one hour or two in the morning (before they go to other work) in making these covers and in this may spend several days. The women admire the creations of their friends and the more experienced ones very often give their welcome advice. No. 1055 shows the beginning of a cover. They only use a needle, (best to sew and tie) a pointed stick (to make the knot) a knife to cut the designs. The designs are cut out without making preliminary indications for the pattern (free hand).Show More >>
Manuscript Catalog Related Archives Finding Aids About Lang-Chapin Congo Expedition

Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: PLANT FIBER, DYE, LEAVES
Dimensions: L:23.5 W:19.3 H:8.6 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: APRON
Category: COSTUME
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: NEGWE. The portion of their clothes that covers their hind. It is very simply adjusted. The lengthened piece on the back is simply pushed down the natural furrow, the string between the narrow and flat piece. The MANGBETU women do not like that their hind quarters are exposed to the looks of men, but when making their toilet they are well satisfied to take a piece not larger than the width of a finger for covering this portion of their backside. In front they take then a piece of bark cloth the size of their hand, so as to cover just that portion which is covered with hair. In this one branch the women create the most astonishing variety of patterns and each woman changes the pattern continually. Some even decorate it by cutting in black human figures, monkeys, etc. (See Nos. 1050 - 1051). As a rule they use only banana leaves in making them. The rough blackened leaves are the reddish leaves that cover the long flours [sic, flowers?] of plantains. They are easily blackened and have a greater resistance. They also use occasionally leaves of corn. They are very white ones, like No. 1022. Others have a sort of hood, like Nos. 1017, 1031, 1032, 1034, which very nicely covers the hollow near the base of the spine. Formerly much in use, now it is difficult to get them. There are only two women in the village of OKONDO who know how to make them. They are woven of bast. Some have a lengthened portion that lays flat on the back like No. l018 & 1049. They arrange first the leaves and s...ew bast through. They sometimes produce good patterns as may be seen also by Nos. 986, 988, 983 & 985. Very few of the women are able to do this kind of work. Usually it takes about a day to make one of these covers for their back, but they never work continuously. As may be seen by No. 1052, the leaves are first sliced deep and pressed between the mats of their bed. They sleep upon a week or so sometimes there are several bunches like this between the mats for future working. The outside leaves are then collected and blackened. They usually work one hour or two in the morning (before they go to other work) in making these covers and in this may spend several days. The women admire the creations of their friends and the more experienced ones very often give their welcome advice. No. 1055 shows the beginning of a cover. They only use a needle, (best to sew and tie) a pointed stick (to make the knot) a knife to cut the designs. The designs are cut out without making preliminary indications for the pattern (free hand).Show More >>
Manuscript Catalog Related Archives Finding Aids About Lang-Chapin Congo Expedition

They usually work one hour or two in the morning (before they go to other work) in making these covers and in this may spend several days. The women admire the creations of their friends and the more experienced ones very often give their welcome advice. No. 1055 shows the beginning of a cover. They only use a needle, (best to sew and tie) a pointed stick (to make the knot) a knife to cut the designs. The designs are cut out without making preliminary indications for the pattern (free hand).Show More >>
Manuscript Catalog Related Archives Finding Aids About Lang-Chapin Congo Expedition
 
 
APRON
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4394
Culture: MANGBETU?
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: PLANT FIBER, CORD, LEAVES, DYE
Dimensions: L:24.2 W:19.2 H:9.5 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: APRON
Category: COSTUME
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: NEGWE. The portion of their clothes that covers their hind. It is very simply adjusted. The lengthened piece on the back is simply pushed down the natural furrow, the string between the narrow and flat piece. The MANGBETU women do not like that their hind quarters are exposed to the looks of men, but when making their toilet they are well satisfied to take a piece not larger than the width of a finger for covering this portion of their backside. In front they take then a piece of bark cloth the size of their hand, so as to cover just that portion which is covered with hair. In this one branch the women create the most astonishing variety of patterns and each woman changes the pattern continually. Some even decorate it by cutting in black human figures, monkeys, etc. (See Nos. 1050 - 1051). As a rule they use only banana leaves in making them. The rough blackened leaves are the reddish leaves that cover the long flours [sic, flowers?] of plantains. They are easily blackened and have a greater resistance. They also use occasionally leaves of corn. They are very white ones, like No. 1022. Others have a sort of hood, like Nos. 1017, 1031, 1032, 1034, which very nicely covers the hollow near the base of the spine. Formerly much in use, now it is difficult to get them. There are only two women in the village of OKONDO who know how to make them. They are woven of bast. Some have a lengthened portion that lays flat on the back like No. l018 & 1049. They arrange first the leaves and s...ew bast through. They sometimes produce good patterns as may be seen also by Nos. 986, 988, 983 & 985. Very few of the women are able to do this kind of work. Usually it takes about a day to make one of these covers for their back, but they never work continuously. As may be seen by No. 1052, the leaves are first sliced deep and pressed between the mats of their bed. They sleep upon a week or so sometimes there are several bunches like this between the mats for future working. The outside leaves are then collected and blackened. They usually work one hour or two in the morning (before they go to other work) in making these covers and in this may spend several days. The women admire the creations of their friends and the more experienced ones very often give their welcome advice. No. 1055 shows the beginning of a cover. They only use a needle, (best to sew and tie) a pointed stick (to make the knot) a knife to cut the designs. The designs are cut out without making preliminary indications for the pattern (free hand).Show More >>

SANDALS
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION

Culture: MANGBETU

Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)

Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: SANDAL
Category: COSTUME
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: KATALLA. A sort of wooden sandals with high heels and raised front. This pair has been made by the MANGBETU, but they are really adopted from the ARABISES (BANGWANA) and used chiefly by soldiers and workmen. There are several men who wear them (only in the morning or on rainy days) in OKONDO'S place.

Manuscript Catalog Related Archives Finding Aids About Lang-Chapin Congo Expedition
 
 
APRON
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4418
Culture: MANGBETU?
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: PLANT FIBER, DYE, LEAVES
Dimensions: L:20 W:18 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: APRON
Category: COSTUME
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: A selection from Okondo's women; the form and pattern changes entirely according to taste; each women as a rule makes these things herself; The principal women however have every thing made by other women who are known by their cleverness in the different branches of handicraft. The fine leather-cord is however made by men only .These are samples that are preferably worn during dances. The MANGBETU are fond if they have everything on their body that sways about. These larger specimens are not fastened to their cord. (They only have been fastened for packing), but are just pushed below the cord. During dances they take a horizontal position and very often the woman is looking down if really this portion as well as the braided portion is popping up and down and swaying as they would like to see it.

The fibres are blackened in mud.

APRON
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4448
Culture: MANGBETU?
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: PLANT FIBER, CORD, LEAVES
Dimensions: L:30 W:12 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: APRON
Category: COSTUME
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: A selection from Okondo's women; the form and pattern changes entirely according to taste; each women as a rule makes these things herself; The principal women however have every thing made by other women who are known by their cleverness in the different branches of handicraft. The fine leather-cord is however made by men only .These are samples that are preferably worn during dances. The MANGBETU are fond if they have everything on their body that sways about. These larger specimens are not fastened to their cord. (They only have been fastened for packing), but are just pushed below the cord. During dances they take a horizontal position and very often the woman is looking down if really this portion as well as the braided portion is popping up and down and swaying as they would like to see it.
Manuscript Catalog Related Archives Finding Aids About Lang-Chapin Congo Expedition

LOIN COVERING
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4451
Culture: ZANDE
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: PLANT FIBER, CORD
Dimensions: L:47 W:45 H:16.5 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: LOIN COVERING
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: A loin covering worn by circumsized [sic, circumcised] boys of the AZANDE, called 'MATADA.' The age of the boys varies considerably about from 6 to 12 years. The boys live in a hut in the bush about a month or two. They are not allowed to go the water. Drinking water and food is regularly brought by their mothers or other women (even large sisters). The women always use a circular pad (put between the jars and their head) which is put over a flexible tall stem nearby the hut (about 20 yards) from it. The women only see the boys that are sick, the healing of the wounds is said to last sometimes up to two months. When the boys are well, there is a great festival with dances and plenty of beer. The boys are all going to the water and washing themselves for the first time. The wound is washed with hot water and some plants are used to envelop the penis.
Manuscript Catalog Related Archives Finding Aids About Lang-Chapin Congo Expedition
 
 
UNFINISHED CARRYING STRAP
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4452
Culture: MANGBETU?
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)

Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: CARRYING STRAP (UNFINISHED)
Category: EQUIPMENT
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: NAIGOGO. A needleworked band with which they carry children. (EPI =) The needle is still attached as it is unfinished. One photograph has been made. These broad bands are made by men or seldom by women. No accessories but the needle are used. They stretch it over their knees and finish in this way.

At the present time it is an extraordinary event to see OKONDO in native cloth. He has practically nothing and the few things he had are nearly all in the collection.

HEADDRESS
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4463
Culture: MANGBETU?
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: FEATHERS, LEATHER, HIDE, FUR
Dimensions: L:41.5 W:39 H:15.5 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: HEADDRESS
Category: COSTUME
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: NOTUKU. The king's hat in which he danced and was photographed. It was difficult to get it, he would not like to depart with the large bunch of cut feathers from a harpy-like eagle, which is very scarce. The bird is called 'ETUMU.' This bunch hangs down behind. In front the bunch of red feathers mounted on a bone pin is fastened. They call them 'NOMBROKUDU.' On the sides he had two huge bunches made of the feathers of guinea fowls, unfortunately he had given them away. OKONDO gave me at the same time the small bunch of red feathers to be fastened on top of the hats.
Exhibition History
• AFRICAN REFLECTIONS: ART FROM NORTHEASTERN ZAIRE. AMNH, NEW YORK, NY. June 1990 - February 1994
Exhibition Label: Eagle feathers, worn by Chief Okondo as part of his dancing hat.
Manuscript Catalog Related Archives Finding Aids About Lang-Chapin Congo Expedition

Culture: MANGBETU
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: BARKCLOTH, PIGMENT
Dimensions: L:38.8 W:32.6 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: BARKCLOTH
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: ASIASI (ASIASI). A selection of pieces of bark cloth as worn by the women upon their right shoulder. These little pieces are nearly always carried about and whenever a woman sits down she lays it first upon the stool. She seldom would sit down without having laid previously such a little piece of bark cloth upon the spot she wants to sit down. These are collected from OKONDO'S women.
Manuscript Catalog Related Archives Finding Aids About Lang-Chapin Congo Expedition

BARK CLOTH
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4482 A
Culture: MANGBETU
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: BARK CLOTH, PIGMENT
Dimensions: L:80.5 W:49 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: BARKCLOTH
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: ANDROGI (= cloth for women) also called ASIASI. A selection of pieces of bark cloth as worn (there are two new ones) by the women of OKONDO. The black ones are predominant. The queens were [sic, wear?] always a black one. I saw only once MTUMBANI in a red one. Today the queens seldom wear native dress. They have generally a large ill fitting shirt-like dress made of white and blue like NENSIMA. MTUMBANI prefers a short shirt reaching down the nabel [sic, navel?] and pagne below. All these and the following samples are painted by native artists without interference except that similar designs are usually only found on the walls of the houses inside as well as outside.
Manuscript Catalog Related Archives Finding Aids About Lang-Chapin Congo Expedition

BASKET
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4484
Culture: MANGBETU?
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: PLANT FIBER, WOOD
Dimensions: L:60 W:34 H:32 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: BASKET
Category: CONTAINERS
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: ODUKU. Large basket showing different patterns, used for putting in food such as cooked or otherwise prepared bananas and vegetables also meat and fish. They take bananas leaves and hold it first over the fire. The leaves lose their rigidity and can be handled somewhat like paper. The midrib of the banana leaves is sliced away previously. With such prepared leaves the baskets are carefully laid out or the food is wrapped into. The food of the MANGBETU hereabout is also chiefly vegetable. The heavier sort like bananas are laid on the bottom, than the meat, if present, is folded in separate pieces of banana leaves. Oil, small fish cooked in oil mushrooms are brought in small dishes. All the work with regard to preparation of food is made by women. The baskets are made by men and women alike. The chief use of these baskets in OKONDO'S villages consists in covering the row of empty or filled large pots which decorate the interior of nearly every more conspicuous hut. Opposite the entrance alongside the wall they generally construct a sort of high bench that often runs along the wall from 1/3 to two thirds of its entire circumference. On former days these pots were all filled in the royal house either with oil or other articles and indicated the wealth of its owner. At the present time these pots are empty or a few contain things like string, dried leaves, etc. In some in OKONDO'S hut they put in glass bottles (of white men) filled with their ARAK, which they secretly distill. I h...ave not seen baskets of this sort elsewhere. As all the chiefs are polygamous, OKONDO for instance, must have at least a hundred wives and counting the servants, slaves and young girls, there are certainly more than two hundred women attached to his court. Each one of the more independent women is obliged to send to the royal kitchen baskets filled with food. Here the food of these baskets is put in large wooden dishes after being assorted, which is very simple considering the relative uniformity of the food delivered. It consists principally of prepared bananas, cooked manioc leaves and sometimes meat. This food is delivered to the ever present guests of the royal court. The food in general varies considerably, considering that nearly everything is considered comestible. Caterpillars, grasshoppers, termites, toads, frogs, snakes (they cut the head off), mice in fact everything is good eating. In OKONDO'S village they eat house rats that are despised so far as I could ascertain in all the region we visited further south, such tribes as the MEDJE, MALELE, MABUTU, MAYOKO, never eat house rats. OKONDO himself is very fond of rats which are delivered him by his natives spiked on sticks and smoked. The king at the present eats without any ceremony, before the crowd or his women, in native fashion with the fingers. I saw him eat banas [sic, bananas], sombe, mice, etc. Whenever he is hungry one of his women goes in the kitchen and brings something back wrapped in banana leaves. He lays it on the little bench and its it (at all times of the day). The principal meals, however, are in the early morning, at noon and near or after nightfall. NOTE: In 1913 he was no more eaten in the public places but either was eating in his hut or behind in one hut in which his sorcerers work the MAPINGA.Show More >>

BASKET
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4485
Culture: MANGBETU?
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: PLANT FIBER
Dimensions: H:21 D:25 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: BASKET
Category: CONTAINERS
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: ODUKU. Large basket showing different patterns, used for putting in food such as cooked or otherwise prepared bananas and vegetables also meat and fish. They take bananas leaves and hold it first over the fire. The leaves lose their rigidity and can be handled somewhat like paper. The midrib of the banana leaves is sliced away previously. With such prepared leaves the baskets are carefully laid out or the food is wrapped into. The food of the MANGBETU hereabout is also chiefly vegetable. The heavier sort like bananas are laid on the bottom, than the meat, if present, is folded in separate pieces of banana leaves. Oil, small fish cooked in oil mushrooms are brought in small dishes. All the work with regard to preparation of food is made by women. The baskets are made by men and women alike. The chief use of these baskets in OKONDO'S villages consists in covering the row of empty or filled large pots which decorate the interior of nearly every more conspicuous hut. Opposite the entrance alongside the wall they generally construct a sort of high bench that often runs along the wall from 1/3 to two thirds of its entire circumference. On former days these pots were all filled in the royal house either with oil or other articles and indicated the wealth of its owner. At the present time these pots are empty or a few contain things like string, dried leaves, etc. In some in OKONDO'S hut they put in glass bottles (of white men) filled with their ARAK, which they secretly distill. I h...ave not seen baskets of this sort elsewhere. As all the chiefs are polygamous, OKONDO for instance, must have at least a hundred wives and counting the servants, slaves and young girls, there are certainly more than two hundred women attached to his court. Each one of the more independent women is obliged to send to the royal kitchen baskets filled with food. Here the food of these baskets is put in large wooden dishes after being assorted, which is very simple considering the relative uniformity of the food delivered. It consists principally of prepared bananas, cooked manioc leaves and sometimes meat. This food is delivered to the ever present guests of the royal court. The food in general varies considerably, considering that nearly everything is considered comestible. Caterpillars, grasshoppers, termites, toads, frogs, snakes (they cut the head off), mice in fact everything is good eating. In OKONDO'S village they eat house rats that are despised so far as I could ascertain in all the region we visited further south, such tribes as the MEDJE, MALELE, MABUTU, MAYOKO, never eat house rats. OKONDO himself is very fond of rats which are delivered him by his natives spiked on sticks and smoked. The king at the present eats without any ceremony, before the crowd or his women, in native fashion with the fingers. I saw him eat banas [sic, bananas], sombe, mice, etc. Whenever he is hungry one of his women goes in the kitchen and brings something back wrapped in banana leaves. He lays it on the little bench and its it (at all times of the day). The principal meals, however, are in the early morning, at noon and near or after nightfall. NOTE: In 1913 he was no more eaten in the public places but either was eating in his hut or behind in one hut in which his sorcerers work the MAPINGA.Show More >>

Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: EGOGNO. Baskets, square somewhat high, provided with closely fitting cover sliding inside. The cover can be fastened. The corners are reinforced by wood. They are always provided with a sort of strap to be hung up in the hut on the pole, etc. They are cockroach-proof. No. 1320 is made of rattan (from NENSIMA). They put in smaller objects of decoration or general wear.

Curatorial Notes: This is a Central African Zande basket. "Baskets like this one held cooked foods such as bananas, vegetables, meat, and fish. Before food was placed in the basket, it was lined with banana leaves that had been held over a fire to give them a papery consistency. Chiefs' wives cooked food and delivered it to the royal court in baskets prepared this way (108)." - Schildkrout, Enid, and C. Keim. African Reflections: Art from Northeastern Zaire. New York and Seattle: AMNH and University of Washington Press, 1990.

I saw him eat banas [sic, bananas], sombe, mice, etc. Whenever he is hungry one of his women goes in the kitchen and brings something back wrapped in banana leaves. He lays it on the little bench and its it (at all times of the day). The principal meals, however, are in the early morning, at noon and near or after nightfall. NOTE: In 1913 he was no more eaten in the public places but either was eating in his hut or behind in one hut in which his sorcerers work the MAPINGA.Show More >>

BASKET
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4499
Culture: MANGBETU?
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: PLANT FIBER
Dimensions: L:41.5 W:27 H:6.5 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1963 [GIFT]
Donor: SUDAN MUSEUM, DEPARTMENT OF ANTIQUITIES
Keywords: BASKET
Category: CONTAINERS
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: ODUKU. Large basket showing different patterns, used for putting in food such as cooked or otherwise prepared bananas and vegetables also meat and fish. They take bananas leaves and hold it first over the fire. The leaves lose their rigidity and can be handled somewhat like paper. The midrib of the banana leaves is sliced away previously. With such prepared leaves the baskets are carefully laid out or the food is wrapped into. The food of the MANGBETU hereabout is also chiefly vegetable. The heavier sort like bananas are laid on the bottom, than the meat, if present, is folded in separate pieces of banana leaves. Oil, small fish cooked in oil mushrooms are brought in small dishes. All the work with regard to preparation of food is made by women. The baskets are made by men and women alike. The chief use of these baskets in OKONDO'S villages consists in covering the row of empty or filled large pots which decorate the interior of nearly every more conspicuous hut. Opposite the entrance alongside the wall they generally construct a sort of high bench that often runs along the wall from 1/3 to two thirds of its entire circumference. On former days these pots were all filled in the royal house either with oil or other articles and indicated the wealth of its owner. At the present time these pots are empty or a few contain things like string, dried leaves, etc. In some in OKONDO'S hut they put in glass bottles (of white men) filled with their ARAK, which they secretly distill. I h...ave not seen baskets of this sort elsewhere. As all the chiefs are polygamous, OKONDO for instance, must have at least a hundred wives and counting the servants, slaves and young girls, there are certainly more than two hundred women attached to his court. Each one of the more independent women is obliged to send to the royal kitchen baskets filled with food. Here the food of these baskets is put in large wooden dishes after being assorted, which is very simple considering the relative uniformity of the food delivered. It consists principally of prepared bananas, cooked manioc leaves and sometimes meat. This food is delivered to the ever present guests of the royal court. The food in general varies considerably, considering that nearly everything is considered comestible. Caterpillars, grasshoppers, termites, toads, frogs, snakes (they cut the head off), mice in fact everything is good eating. In OKONDO'S village they eat house rats that are despised so far as I could ascertain in all the region we visited further south, such tribes as the MEDJE, MALELE, MABUTU, MAYOKO, never eat house rats. OKONDO himself is very fond of rats which are delivered him by his natives spiked on sticks and smoked. The king at the present eats without any ceremony, before the crowd or his women, in native fashion with the fingers. I saw him eat banas [sic, bananas], sombe, mice, etc. Whenever he is hungry one of his women goes in the kitchen and brings something back wrapped in banana leaves. He lays it on the little bench and its it (at all times of the day). The principal meals, however, are in the early morning, at noon and near or after nightfall. NOTE: In 1913 he was no more eaten in the public places but either was eating in his hut or behind in one hut in which his sorcerers work the MAPINGA.Show More >>

HAT
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4503
Culture: MANGBETU
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: PLANT FIBER
Dimensions: L:27 H:12.5 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: HAT
Category: COSTUME
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: NOTUKU. The king's hat in which he danced and was photographed. It was difficult to get it, he would not like to depart with the large bunch of cut feathers from a harpy-like eagle, which is very scarce. The bird is called 'ETUMU.' This bunch hangs down behind. In front the bunch of red feathers mounted on a bone pin is fastened. They call them 'NOMBROKUDU.' On the sides he had two huge bunches made of the feathers of guinea fowls, unfortunately he had given them away. OKONDO gave me at the same time the small bunch of red feathers to be fastened on top of the hats.
Manuscript Catalog Related Archives Finding Aids About Lang-Chapin Congo Expedition

BASKET
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4506
Culture: MANGBETU?
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: PLANT FIBER, WOOD
Dimensions: L:32 W:28 H:11.5 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: BASKET
Category: CONTAINERS
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: EDSHEGERE. Sieves used also in the preparation of termites. They put them in the sun to dry them after having cleaned them. Also used in the preparation of the kernels of the calabashes after being dried in the sun. They crush it and sieve the flour. The principal use, however, is for the preparation of a roux (of fluid) porridge-like drink ABODA (called by white men Pot-au-pot) which is prepared from dried manioc and flour of eleusine. When well cooked, they filter it or rather sieve it over. By means of the these sieves they are gently moved over the pot and the rest is thrown away. The ANA is more in use with the AZANDE. The MANGBETU prefer the beer-like drink. NOTE: ANA or AURVA is the beer of the MANGBETU called in BANGALA, MASANGA. (The manioc in the preparation of -Aboda -is -first cleaned of its out in the manner of potatoes then it is put during two days in the water, -it is cut to pieces and crushed in the morter [sic, mortar] and boiled -in a -large -pot during about 6 hours, -the manioc is thrown---Information unclear. It is crossed out in the original notes)
Manuscript Catalog Related Archives Finding Aids About Lang-Chapin Congo Expedition

Field Notes: ADUKU. Hats like Nos. 1213, 1210 & 1214 are worn only by older men. The other hats are a selection of their best work. Here the hats are made only by men. All such hats are called ODUKU.
